channel.title: Chaotic Good Computing
channel.description: Last 40 notes on Chaotic Good Computing

item.title: Quartz Widgets: Graphs, Galore!
item.description: I killed 4 of my blogs trying to implement MDX support. Will this one be next? Using MDX with Quartz to create interactive graphs, diagrams, and demos — clear as day.

item.title: Intro to Event Storming
item.description: Notes from learning Event Storming for domain-driven design. Thoughts on phases, color-coded chaos, and how to transition from fast pitches to full products.

item.title: Kickoff: Season of Systems
item.description: I'm learning to live with the systems that stole my beloved em-dash. A season dedicated to negotiating how to live with the agentic models that have turned my career upside-down.

item.title: LLMs; or, How to Run Your Own Hostage Negotiation
item.description: LLMs: Are we doomed to die, or born to garden? I'd like to make the case that AI is less like Terminator, and more like tomatoes.

item.title: Review: Season of Rhythm
item.description: Looking back at my year-long attempt to build sustainable habits after finishing undergrad. A retrospective on routines, remote work transitions, and learning to go slow-and-steady.

item.title: Typst Resume Template
item.description: A beginner-friendly resume template in Typst — 100% less LaTeX, 100% more opinions.

item.title: Terraform LocalStack Testing
item.description: $70/mo/seat? Just using live AWS may be cheaper. An evaluation of LocalStack as a testbed for Account Factory Terraform.

item.title: The Simple Economics of Open Source
item.description: Why do we do what we do? "Egoboo." Exploring economic models of OSS contributions beyond altruism and ego.

item.title: College Admissions and the Stability of Marriage
item.description: A dive into the hottest algorithm of the 1960s: Gale-Shapley matchmaking. Who knew that the mysteries of the heart could be solved with a matrix?

item.title: Feeling Right, Nothing Done: Don't Be the Death of Consensus
item.description: Classifying opinions as "strong" or "weak" to stop wasting hours in fruitless engineering debates. How consensus can beat being "right", and an open letter for the tactically apathetic.

item.title: Before You Slabtop Your Laptop: A Brief Warning
item.description: PSA: Check if your laptop needs an LCD for POST before removing the screen. Learned this the hard way after 5 hours and a fried motherboard. Learn from my dumb mistakes.

item.title: GPTinglish: The New Normal
item.description: The only market crashing is the market for sanitized language. Stay human. Embrace typos.

item.title: Arc Browser: Kicking off the Season of Rhythm
item.description: A review 3 years in the making for Arc Browser, the browser that ignited my burning passion for vertical tabs and keyboard shortcuts.

item.title: Turning SelfControl into Self Restraint
item.description: Building a Raycast plugin to schedule website blocks — because checking news "just one more time" destroys flow. Automate SelfControl and self control: take your laptop back.

item.title: Diary of a Raycastaway
item.description: A MacOS Spotlight replacement I'd recommend to everybody, not just engineers. Brief thoughts on Raycast before diving into extensions and workflows.

item.title: Caveat Lector: Reader Beware
item.description: I'm embracing being wrong on the internet in an effort to learn in public. A disclaimer on digital gardening, dead pixels, and the fear of terminal online-ness.

item.title: Unstable Marriage
item.description: After researching matchmaking algorithms forever, I never considered odd-numbered sets. The implications are funnier than expected — addendum on Gale-Shapley matchmaking.

item.title: The Quest to Slay The Goblin
item.description: My life devolves into sleep-eat-procrastinate cycles without structure—I call this "The Goblin." Productivity tools, hating on hustle culture, and a new definition for horticulture.

item.title: Some initial thoughts about time tracking
item.description: TODO.

item.title: Quantitative Analysis of Markets & Organizations
item.description: My time at the University of Utah was longer than I'd planned, cut shorter than expected by COVID-19. I was very lucky to have mentorship to push me across the finish line.

item.title: Breaking Ground on Digital Gardening
item.description: Why I stopped hoarding 60%-done drafts and started publishing messy thoughts instead. Embracing digital gardening, from-chaos-to-cultivated, and a healthy dose of imperfection.

item.title: Kickoff: Season of Rhythm
item.description: "Fight or flight" is a rough way to treat white-collar life. My Season of Rhythm is dedicated to transitioning from constant sprints to slow-and-steady.

item.title: The Over/Unders of Over- and Under-Engineering
item.description: I've learned so much in my career — so why do I finish fewer projects than I used to? Over-engineering: it's easier to be bad at something on accident than on purpose.

item.title: In Review: The (bad) 2017 Robloxaville Remaster
item.description: How over-engineering killed a 3-month remaster of an old ROBLOX game. Looking back at the depth of Dunning-Kruger, and how good code doesn't make a good game.

item.title: Don't Double Down: Structured Streaming to Wrangle Data
item.description: Stop reprocessing your entire dataset every time new data arrives. A practical guide to Spark Structured Streaming with code examples and cost logic.

item.title: Littlefield Simulator: The Art of Laziness
item.description: Efficiency: spending six hours building a web scraper to avoid five minutes of daily work. Automating a business simulation because checking in is for chumps.

item.title: The Unbearable Weight of ROBLOX Celebrity
item.description: Being famous online in 2009 is the highest high I'll ever reach. A love letter to the coolest dork I know, hatemail for client-side exploits, and a limitless supply of Monopoly dollars.

item.title: Say Goodbye to Untitled (5) — GitHub Actions for Resumes
item.description: Set up continuous integration to auto-update your resume everywhere. Overleaf, GitHub, and LaTeX automation for the perpetually disorganized.

item.title: Hello, Blog! (Posts by a dummy, for other dummies)
item.description: The obligatory "Hello!" post to suss out what this site will be. Python examples as unnecessary as the post itself.

item.title: Entries to SOME 1
item.description: Stable matching, optimal stopping, and Bachelor analysis - visualized with some care.

item.title: Utah Office Consult
item.description: People problems are the hardest engineering problems. A consult on thinking out-of-the-box to explain morale problems in small companies.

item.title: College Admissions and the Stability of Marriage
item.description: My college presentation on the Gale-Shapley paper, recorded on an iPad, like a true professional. Non-market environments, matchmaking lattices, and gratitude for good professors.

item.title: Reading the Room with Beethoven
item.description: A HackTheU 2019 project for real-time live captioning using remote microphones.

item.title: What *are* Supply Chains, Anyway?
item.description: A first foray into network visualization: messy graphs, abject terror. Early data viz experiments searching for supply loops. Bad graphs; interesting questions.

item.title: Scratch Piano Application
item.description: An educational waveform visualizer written in everybody's favorite programming language: Scratch.

item.title: Quicksort: Every CS Student's Favorite Algorithm, Scratched Up
item.description: Implementing QuickSort in Scratch. Its only real-world accomplishment? Wearing out my mouse's scroll bar.
